Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis and Characterization of Two-Dimensional Mn+1Xn Layers Derived from the MAX Phases
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Atomically thin two-dimensional (2D) materials have unique properties compared to their conventional three-dimensional counterparts. Graphene, which is a single atomic layer of carbon, is the most illustrious and studied of these newly emerging 2D materials. Graphene, however, is limited to just one element - carbon. Recently, a new family of 2D early transition metal (e.g. titanium, vanadium, niobium, etc.) carbides and carbonitrides (so called MXene) was reported. These 2D materials offer a large variety of chemical compositions compared to graphene and they can exist in different numbers of atomic layers. MXenes may have a wide range of potential applications, ranging from composite reinforcements, to industrial catalysts, to energy storage and electronic devices. Before the best application can be identified, however, the fundamental physics of these materials must be developed and the synthesis-structure-property relationships must be established. Combined experimental and theoretical work will be used to understand the surface chemistry, structure and properties of MXenes compounds. This work could result in batteries that charge in minutes for thousands of cycles or robust supercapacitors that can be used for very high power energy storage applications such as regenerative breaking in cars.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Recently, a new family of 2D early transition metal (e.g. titanium, vanadium, niobium, etc.) carbides and carbonitrides (so called MXene) was discovered. The latter offer a large variety of chemical compositions, as multiple atoms can co-exist in the 2D sheets. Furthermore MXenes exist in 3, 5 or 7 atomic layers. The as-synthesized MXene surfaces are functionalized with OH, O, and/or F. Theoretical calculations predict that the MXenes can be either conductors or semiconductors depending on their surface chemistry. MXenes may have a wide range of potential applications, ranging from composite reinforcements, to industrial catalysts, to energy storage and electronic devices. Since this class of solids is quite new, the fundamental basic science of these materials must be developed and their synthesis-structure-property relationships need to be established. The aims of this project are: (i) isolate single MXene layers on different substrates, (ii) determine whether these layers have attractive electronic properties like graphene and could thus be used as transistors, (iii) measure the electrical and optical characteristics of these films, as a function of surface terminations and MXene chemistry, (iv) disperse the 2D sheets in various solvents, including water, and form stable suspensions, (v) use various spectroscopy techniques to investigate MXene surfaces and correlate them to theoretical first principles calculations to fully understand the surface chemistry and its effect on properties, (vi) investigate how MXene surfaces can be chemically functionalized and understand the effects of such functionalization on the aforementioned properties, and (vii) spin-coat MXene thin films and measure their optical and transport properties. This work offers exciting research opportunities for students - undergraduate students will be trained on state of the art equipment and graduate students will work towards their doctorates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

MXene - a large family of two-dimensional, 2D, nanomaterials discovered by our research groups in 2011 - exhibit a combination of properties unattainable in other 2D materials. More specifically, thery combine high electrical conductivity, diverse transition metal chemistries, tunable surface functionalization, and hydrophilicity. In turn, these materials have shown great promise for energy storage, catalytic supports, conductive transparent electrodes, electromagnetic shielding, and sensors, among many other applications. The work supported by grant 1310245 built upon this seminal work and led to the discovery of new MXenes (e.g. titanium and chromium nitride MXenes and new carbide-based MXenes), fundamental understanding of their physical properties, and how the properties vary with MXene composition and surface chemistry. Moreover, safer and/or more time and resource efficient wet-chemical and gas-phase synthesis and colloidal processing methods were developed which allowed their subsequent deposition of MXene into thick and thin films or their incorporation into multifunctional polymer composites. Fundamental insights on the interactions of MXenes with water and cations showed that these materials behave remarkably similar to layered silicate clays, despite having high electrical conductivities unlike clays. This is a first among the various classes of 2D materials. Our fundamental studies of MXene have also allowed us to gain more insights into their electronic transport and the their physics.

 Broader Impact

The synthesis and processing advances achieved in this work, have expanded the compositional space of MXene that, in turn, will allow us to better choose the MXene compostions most well-suited for several critical applications of national interest. Significantly, our work on Ti3C2showed unprecedented performance of MXene electrodes and films for high-rate pseudocapacitive energy storage, transparent conductive electrodes, and EMI shielding relative to state-of-the-art commercial materials. These advances were communicated to the international scientific audiences and tens of conference presentations, research symposia, and many peer-reviewed journal articles, which have in turn led to MXene research now being pursued in multiple research groups globally since 2014. Many PhD students and undergraduate students were able to obtain diverse skill sets and develop as independent Materials Science & Engineering researchers as a consequence of being involved in the work supported by this grant. With the strides made in the understanding of MXene under this grant, we are quite optimistic that the properties of MXene can be improved to address various global technological challenges.
